Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of Next Generation Hydrothermal Atomic Force Microscopy
Award.AbstractNarration:
1429545
Eggleston

This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) Program grant supports the development of an atomic force microscope (AFM) capable of in situ imaging of mineral dissolution and growth in aqueous solutions at unprecedented hydrothermal conditions of temperature and pressure (up to 200 degrees C and 20 bars) and will advance molecular-scale imaging capabilities afforded through new scanning probe tip design. The development builds upon a previously successful hydrothermal cell AFM (HAFM) that has the proven capabilities to imagine mineral surface processes in solution but at more limited P/T conditions (P = 12 bars; T = 150 degrees C). The higher P/T space that should be achievable with a so-called next generation HAFM (ngHAFM) will allow for study of the processes of dissolution of aluminosilicates and other refractory phases in aqueous solution under hydrothermal conditions as well as observation of any precipitation of new fragile mineral surface overgrowth phases given that dissolution and mineralization kinetics should be rapid enough to achieve stable AFM imaging to observe these processes. Application to study of host rock demineralization and mineralization consequences of subsurface carbon dioxide sequestration, study of mineral extraction processes, characterization of the robustness of solar panel photovoltaic materials under extreme conditions and studies of material corrosion processes should be advanced by this technology. The development will engage collaboration between an academic institution (the University of Wyoming) and a commercial sector partner (Asylum Research) and will train a postdoctoral researcher in instrument design, fabrication and testing. The potential for patentable technology resultant from this development project is significant.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Atomic force microscopy (AFM) has been a key imaging technology for well over three decades, making possible molecular-scale observations in an unprecedented way with applications in materials science, crystal growth, biotechnology, the electronics industry, and many other applications. One of the key features of the AFM is the ability to image processes, such as crystal growth, at the molecular scale directly within the solutions from which crystals are growing.  Unlike standard electron microscopies, no vacuum is required. Recent technology development by private companies that market AFM systems has made possible new ways of imaging that lead to unprecedented atomic-scale resolution within fluids.  The goal of this project was to bring these technological developments to a new hydrothermal AFM capable of imaging not only in solutions but at elevated temperature and pressure as well.  Our earlier hydrothermal AFM, developed in the 1990s, was successful to 150°C and was patented. In this project, we designed and constructed the "next generation hydrothermal atomic force microscope" (ngHAFM). The goal was to build a miniaturized microscope that could fit within an existing commercial scanning platform to maximize its utility to users. The microscope we developed here is capable of imaging within aqueous solutions at up to 200°C and 20 bars pressure, and had the initial goal of making possible the imaging of crystal growth in geological contexts but it has applications in many industrial contexts as well. Applications of this technology include research on mineral transformations in certain energy contexts and in the context of carbon sequestration and storage in the subsurface. The design and construction of the ngHAFM involved developing some new ideas and technologies, and in the near future we will study the feasibility of further patent applications. We provide some images of the design, the real physical microscope, and the microscope installed in the commercial scanning platform needed to run it.
